text:
RFC 2616, page 76 "When an HTTP message includes the content of a single range
..., this content is transmitted a Content-Range header, and a Content-Length
header showing the number of bytes actually transferred"

I am seeing correct Content-Range responses, but the Content-Length is the
length of the content object, not the data that will be transferred. IE:

Content-Range: bytes 500-600/1234
Content-Length: 1234

which violates the RFC. One can infer the correct content length from the
content-range (since it is correct), but being properly RFC compliant would be
better.

Reproduction case was a simple, single request directly to a standard binary
Apache 2.2.2 build running on Windows.
